articles.headline: Surgery Fixes a Ligament (if It Exists). Does It Fix the Knee?
articles.snippet: A newly defined ligament quickly gave rise to a reconstructive procedure, but orthopedic experts disagree on whether the surgery helps or harms.
articles.abstract: A newly defined ligament quickly gave rise to a reconstructive procedure, but orthopedic experts disagree on whether the surgery helps or harms.
articles.lead_paragraph: For professional athletes and weekend warriors alike, it appeared to be welcome news: the discovery by researchers of a new knee ligament that, if repaired, might help tens of thousands of people with an injury from sports or an accident.

articles.headline: Democrats Struggle for Unity on First Day of Convention
articles.snippet: Supporters of Bernie Sanders, who lost to Hillary Clinton, booed when he urged them to vote for her despite revelations of bias by party leaders.
articles.abstract: Supporters of Bernie Sanders, who lost to Hillary Clinton, booed when he urged them to vote for her despite revelations of bias by party leaders.
articles.lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — Democratic Party leaders scrambled on Monday night to rescue their convention from political bedlam as supporters of Senator Bernie Sanders erupted in boos, jeers and protests against Hillary Clinton after an email leak showed that party officials had sought to undermine Mr. Sanders in their race for the nomination.
articles.byline: By Patrick Healy and Jonathan Martin

articles.headline: Fed Prepares Action Against Goldman Sachs in Leak Case
articles.snippet: Two men already pleaded guilty in the 2014 case, which involved the passing of confidential information from the New York Fed to a Goldman banker.
articles.abstract: Two men already pleaded guilty in the 2014 case, which involved the passing of confidential information from the New York Fed to a Goldman banker.
articles.lead_paragraph: Two years ago, the Federal Reserve faced a predicament: One of its New York employees had leaked confidential government information to a banker at Goldman Sachs.
articles.byline: By Ben Protess and Jessica Silver-Greenberg

articles.headline: Lael Brainard, Donning a Global Lens, Champions Low Rates at Fed
articles.snippet: The Fed is expected to again pass on an opportunity to raise its interest rate, a move partly owing to the efforts of Ms. Brainard, a Fed governor.
articles.abstract: The Fed is expected to again pass on an opportunity to raise its interest rate, a move partly owing to the efforts of Ms. Brainard, a Fed governor.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Lael Brainard is poised to win another round this week in her fight for the Federal Reserve to keep interest rates low.

articles.headline: As ISIS Loosens Grip, U.S. and Iraq Prepare for Grinding Insurgency
articles.snippet: The Islamic State’s suicide attack in Baghdad this month, officials say, foreshadows the violence it will unleash as it reverts to its guerrilla roots.
articles.abstract: The Islamic State’s suicide attack in Baghdad this month, officials say, foreshadows the violence it will unleash as it reverts to its guerrilla roots.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — The Islamic State’s latest suicide attack in Baghdad, which killed nearly 330 people, foreshadows a long and bloody insurgency, according to American diplomats and commanders, as the group reverts to its guerrilla roots because its territory is shrinking in Iraq and Syria.
articles.byline: By Michael S. Schmidt and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: One Thing Both Parties Want: To Break Up the Banks Again
articles.snippet: Bernie Sanders and Donald Trump both called for the reinstatement of Glass-Steagall, a 1933 law that separated investment and commercial banks.
articles.abstract: Bernie Sanders and Donald Trump both called for the reinstatement of Glass-Steagall, a 1933 law that separated investment and commercial banks.
articles.lead_paragraph: Could the Glass-Steagall Act — the Depression-era legislation that forced the separation of investment banking from commercial banking, among other things — be coming back?

articles.headline: To Democrats, Email Hack Suggests Trump Has New Supporter: Putin
articles.snippet: A breach tied to Russian intelligence agencies has raised questions about whether the Kremlin has thrown its support behind Donald J. Trump.
articles.abstract: A breach tied to Russian intelligence agencies has raised questions about whether the Kremlin has thrown its support behind Donald J. Trump.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As Donald J. Trump prepared to take his beauty pageant to Moscow in 2013, he relished the participation of one man above all: President Vladimir V. Putin. “Do you think Putin will be going to The Miss Universe Pageant in November in Moscow — if so, will he become my new best friend?” he wrote on Twitter.
articles.byline: By Steven Lee Myers and Neil MacFarquhar

articles.headline: Michelle Obama Joins Forces With Her Predecessor (and Former Adversary)
articles.snippet: The first lady’s speech in support of Hillary Clinton was a testament to their evolving relationship.
articles.abstract: The first lady’s speech in support of Hillary Clinton was a testament to their evolving relationship.
articles.lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — They began as adversaries, with Michelle Obama often fuming about what she viewed as brutal, unfair attacks by Hillary Clinton on her husband during the 2008 primary campaign.
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear and Mark Landler

articles.headline: Bernie Sanders Faces Task of Putting Down Revolt He Started
articles.snippet: Despite Mr. Sanders’s pleas to unite around Hillary Clinton, his supporters booed, heckled and protested on the first night of the Democratic National Convention.
articles.abstract: Despite Mr. Sanders’s pleas to unite around Hillary Clinton, his supporters booed, heckled and protested on the first night of the Democratic National Convention.
articles.lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — Bernie Sanders likes to boast that he has ignited a fiery movement.
articles.byline: By Michael Barbaro and Yamiche Alcindor

articles.headline: Why Dropping the Trans-Pacific Partnership May Be a Bad Idea
articles.snippet: The pact has few friends left in Washington, but America’s Asian allies may see backing off as a betrayal of Washington’s commitment to the region.
articles.abstract: The pact has few friends left in Washington, but America’s Asian allies may see backing off as a betrayal of Washington’s commitment to the region.
articles.lead_paragraph: It might seem pretty painless, at this juncture, to throw the Trans-Pacific Partnership under the bus.
